Dear Ms. Motsinger:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessical VandenHeuvel, area manager at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB810406448
Licensee Group Organization: Our House
Licensee Designee: Natasha Doan - Motsinger
Chief Administrator: Natasha Doan - Motsinger
Agency Name: Our House- Mosaic

Ypsilanti, MI. 48197-4644
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 01/25/2024

III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504 (3) Eligibility requirements.
Section (3) An independent living home, staffed and operated by the
Description child placing agency, must be clean, safe, and appropriate to
the needs of the youth it serves.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency is not meeting the disability or safety needs of a youth
placed here. They have no wheelchair ramp, leaving youth to
crawl or walk-up steps. Youth's wheelchair was broken by staff.
One youth was using illegal substances on the premises.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 10/26/2023.
The Complainant reported she had no additional information to
report other than what was reported to her by the Independent
Living Youth.
Independent Living Youth (IL Youth) was interviewed via
telephone on 10/26/2023. She reported she gets support from the
staff in her IL placement. She reported she is not provided bus
tokens. She reported she is on the first level of the home and that
everything is in her reach. She said when she cannot reach
something in the kitchen cabinets, the staff or one of her peers
assist her in getting the item. She reported this does not occur
often. IL Youth said she gets around well and does not crawl and
is able to use her walker when walking. She said her wheelchair
was broken but the agency is looking into fixing it. She said not
having the wheelchair is not a hinderance because she has other
means of getting around. She reported she is pregnant. She
reported the home is staffed and someone is there most of the
time. IL Youth reported she only gets $80.00 dollars in food
stamps, and this is not enough. IL youth reported that the person
who was in the program using substance is no longer in the
program. She said there is no illegal substances being used in
the house now. IL Youth reported the youth in the program using
illegal substances was making her feel unsafe. She said she still
sometimes does not feel safe in the home but refused to elaborate
on what that means. She was asked about her safety and feelings
today, she reported she felt safe. She was provided a telephone
number to call this Consultant back if at any time she wanted to
discuss her safety issues. To date, IL Youth has not called.
IL Caseworker was interviewed via video conference on
10/26/2023. She reported that IL Youth is a very intelligent young
lady who graduated from high school at the age of 15. She said IL
Youth is very independent and does not like assistance from
others and enjoys doing tasks for herself. She said she has never
2

observed IL Youth crawling up or down stairs. She said IL Youth
has three walking/moving devices at her disposal that she uses.
She said IL Youth walks up the stairs with ease using her walker
and the railing if needed. The IL Director explained that the front of
the house has stairs. IL Youth is partially mobile and is able to
use the railing to get herself up and down the stairs. She said the
agency tried to get a ramp for IL Youth when she first moved into
the home, but the stairs were too steep, and the ramp was not
safe for wheelchair use due to the angle. She said the agency
tried to go another route to get a ramp, but due to liability, the
company, the agency asked said no. She reported in addition, the
agency is renting the house, so the agency needed the landlord
approval for the agency to take the porch down. She said the
house is very old and the agency would have to get special
permission to have the porch removed.
IL Caseworker reported IL Youth gets around the house very well
using her walker or second wheelchair. She stressed that IL
Youth has up to three moving devices including wheelchairs. She
said one of IL Youth wheelchairs is broken and the agency put in
the order to get the parts that is broken fixed. She said the
agency is waiting for those parts to arrive to schedule the
appointment to fix the wheelchair.
IL Caseworker reported staff assists IL Youth in getting to and
from appointments. She said sometimes IL Youth mother and
grandmother drives her to appointments but it’s usually the
agency staff. IL Caseworker reported their contract does not
include transportation services; this is an extra service the agency
provides. IL Caseworker stated in addition, their contract does not
state the agency has to provide food but that the agency assists
the youths’ with getting a bridge card and the agency has an
emergency pantry in the house. She said the youth have access
to pantries across Washtenaw County and the agency take the
youths on grocery runs weekly.
IL Caseworker reported that IL Youth has shared safety concerns
regarding conflicts centered on another youth in the house. She
said there was a youth in the house that used illegal substances
and was not following the rules of the house or her contract
requirements. She said the youth is no longer in the program and
the conflict that was being caused by this youth is no longer an
issue.
Chief Administrator was interviewed on 10/26/2023 via video
conference. She reported IL Youth moved into the house and the
3

agency measured the first-floor hallway to make sure IL Youth
wheelchair could fit through. She said it could and it does. She
reported IL Youth has a room on the first floor which gives her
access to the kitchen, bathroom, staff office, library, and
gathered/living room. She said IL Youth sometimes goes upstairs
to the second floor but, since the agency put in the rule that
youths may not be in each other’s rooms, there is no longer a
reason for IL Youth to go upstairs as there are only other youths’
rooms and bathrooms on the second floor. Chief Administrator
reported the staff hours are from 4pm to 8am. She said the house
have a support staff starting at 1pm until 5pm or 9pm depending
on the day and need. She said the house also has a shift
manager who can come onsite in case of an emergency.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
• Placement History
IL Youth has been placed 15 times. Her last placement is
with Our House – Mosaic on 3/30/2023. The placement
was observed by DHHS foster care specialist and DHHS
supervisor.
• Social work contacts from 3/30/2023 – 11/1/2023 were
reviewed. There were no safety concerns noted regarding
lack of supervision, or a discussion about a wheelchair
ramp by the DHHS foster care specialist and/or supervisor
from Jackson County DHHS.
• The social work contact dated 11/1/2023 was an FTM
whereby IL Youth participated with DHHS representation,
Our House staff, and IL Youth parent. The discussion
centered around where IL Youth would move into after her
placement from Our House. Discussions was about host
homes, mother – baby housing as well as potentially IL
Youth own apartment with CMH in home assistance.
Washtenaw County DHHS will also look into IL Youth
joining YAVFC program.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as during interviews with youth
and staff, IL Youth is able to access the independent living home
with no concerns using her walker, wheelchair, or staff assistance.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12413 (1)(a) Medical and dental care policy.
Section (1) An agency ‘s medical and dental care policy must
Description include all the following:
4

(a) The provision of routine medical care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency has failed to initiate OT/PT services or enroll client in
MI Rehab.
Investigation The IL Youth was interviewed via telephone on 10/26/2023. She
reported she has attended physical therapy since being in Our
House program. She said staff transport her to her doctor’s
appointments and pick up her medications.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed on 10/26/2023 via video
conference. She reported that IL Youth did have Physical therapy
(PT) and when the insurance company said she could not have
any more sessions, the agency fought back and got her more
sessions, which are now completed. IL Youth was not scheduled
for anymore PT until after her second surgery which was canceled
due to IL Youth being pregnant.
The IL Caseworker reported there was no physical documentation
indicating the agency assisted in providing IL Youth with more PT
appointments. She explained everything was completed by
telephone calls with IL Youth insurance and the agency program
manager. She said the insurance called the agency and stated
they reinstated PT sessions for IL Youth and the agency did not
have to do anything else. IL Youth additional PT sessions were
scheduled for 7/5, 7/14, 8/2, 8/7, 8/18, 8/29, 9/11 and 10/4/2023.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
• Documentation dated 3/25/2022 from Pediatric
Rehabilitation Center, University of Michigan Health Center.
• OT Evaluation/treatment – 3/25/22 – expires 6/12/22.
• PT Evaluation/treatment – 3/26/22 – expires 12/2022.
Analysis Due to the dates provided from the agency on IL Youth additional
PT sessions, the agency is providing appropriate services to IL
Youth.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISH
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency current license
status be continued.
11/22/2023
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
November 28, 2023
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
6
